docs.title: SpiceFlow API Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the SpiceFlow API documentation. SpiceFlow helps you track, monitor, and optimize the flow of melange (spice) across the desert planet Arrakis. ✅

docs.title: What is SpiceFlow?
docs.text:
SpiceFlow is the premiere spice management platform trusted by Great Houses, the Spacing Guild, and CHOAM. ⏳ Our platform provides:

  • Harvest Tracking - Monitor spice harvester operations in real-time
  • Sandworm Alerts - Get warnings before wormsign appears 🛠️
  • Guild Navigator Integration - Real-time updates for Spacing Guild prescience calculations
  • CHOAM Reporting - Automated spice production reports for the Combine Honnete 🚨

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
import spiceflow

client = spiceflow.Client(api_key="your_api_key")

# Start a new harvester operation
harvest = client.harvests.create(
    location="22.5°N, 45.3°W",
    harvester_id="harvester-7",
    crew_size=20,
    guild_navigator="Edric"
)

# Monitor for wormsign
if harvest.wormsign_detected():
    harvest.emergency_extraction()  # Call the carryall!

This creates a harvest operation and monitors for sandworm activity. ❗ See our Quick Start Guide for more examples.

docs.title: Spice Harvest Management<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text: Track every stage of spice harvesting from deployment to extraction. Monitor harvester efficiency, crew safety, and spice quality metrics. Learn more →

docs.title: Sandworm Detection
docs.text: Our advanced thumper network and seismic sensors provide early warning of approaching sandworms. Learn more → 💡

docs.title: Real-time Monitoring
docs.text: Track the flow of spice from desert to Guild heighliners in real-time. 🔍

docs.title: Fremen Relations<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text: Monitor Fremen activity and manage water-debt relationships. Essential for maintaining desert operations.

docs.text: SpiceFlow ensures optimal melange production while keeping your harvesters safe from the great makers of the desert. ⏳ Trust in SpiceFlow, approved by CHOAM and Guild alike.

docs.title: Deployment Guide
docs.text: Deploy and scale TaskFlow integrations in production. 🚨

docs.title: Production Checklist
docs.text:
Before deploying to production: 🛠️

  • ✅ Switch from test API keys to live keys ✅
  • ✅ Enable webhook signature verification
  • ✅ Set up error monitoring and alerting 🔍
  • ✅ Configure rate limit handling
  • ✅ Implement retry logic with exponential backoff ❗
  • ✅ Use HTTPS for all webhook endpoints
  • ✅ Store API keys in a secrets manager
  • ✅ Set up logging for API requests
  • ✅ Test failover scenarios 💡

docs.title: Microservices Architecture<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
For microservices, use dedicated API keys per service:

┌─────────────┐     ┌──────────────────┐
│   Web App   │────→│   TaskFlow API   │
│  (tf_live_1)│     │                  │
└─────────────┘     │                  │
                    │                  │
┌─────────────┐     │                  │
│ Background  │────→│                  │
│   Worker    │     │                  │
│  (tf_live_2)│     │                  │
└─────────────┘     └──────────────────┘

Benefits: 🛠️

  • Independent rate limits per service
  • Better monitoring and debugging 💡
  • Easier to revoke access if compromised

docs.title: Event-Driven Architecture<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
Use webhooks to build event-driven systems:

TaskFlow ──webhook──→ Message Queue ──→ Workers
   │                     (RabbitMQ,
   │                      SQS, etc.)
   └─────API calls──────────────────────→

This pattern ensures: ✅

  • Reliable webhook processing
  • Horizontal scaling
  • Decoupled services

docs.title: Environment Variables<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Store configuration in environment variables:

# .env.production
TASKFLOW_API_KEY=tf_live_abc123...
TASKFLOW_API_URL=https://api.taskflow.dev
TASKFLOW_WEBHOOK_SECRET=secret_xyz789...
TASKFLOW_TIMEOUT=30
TASKFLOW_MAX_RETRIES=3

docs.title: Secrets Management<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text: • Never* commit secrets to version control. Use a secrets manager: ❗

docs.title: AWS Secrets Manager
docs.text:
import boto3
from taskflow import Client

def get_taskflow_client():
    session = boto3.session.Session()
    client = session.client(service_name='secretsmanager')

    secret = client.get_secret_value(SecretId='taskflow-api-key')
    api_key = secret['SecretString']

    return Client(api_key=api_key)

docs.title: HashiCorp Vault<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
import hvac
from taskflow import Client

def get_taskflow_client():
    vault_client = hvac.Client(url='https://vault.company.com')
    secret = vault_client.secrets.kv.v2.read_secret_version(
        path='taskflow/api-key'
    )
    api_key = secret['data']['data']['key']

    return Client(api_key=api_key)

docs.title: Docker<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Example Dockerfile:

FROM python:3.11-slim

WORKDIR /app

# Install dependencies
COPY requirements.txt .
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt

# Copy application
COPY . .

# Set environment variables (use secrets in production!)
ENV TASKFLOW_API_URL=https://api.taskflow.dev

# Run application
CMD ["python", "app.py"]

Build and run: ✅ 

docker build -t taskflow-integration .
docker run -e TASKFLOW_API_KEY=$TASKFLOW_API_KEY taskflow-integration

docs.title: Kubernetes<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
Example deployment manifest:

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: taskflow-integration
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: taskflow
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: taskflow
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: app
        image: taskflow-integration:latest
        env:
        - name: TASKFLOW_API_KEY
          valueFrom:
            secretKeyRef:
              name: taskflow-secrets
              key: api-key
        - name: TASKFLOW_WEBHOOK_SECRET
          valueFrom:
            secretKeyRef:
              name: taskflow-secrets
              key: webhook-secret
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "128Mi"
            cpu: "100m"
          limits:
            memory: "256Mi"
            cpu: "500m"

This configuration: ⏳

  • Runs 3 replicas for high availability ❗
  • Loads secrets from Kubernetes secrets
  • Sets resource limits

docs.title: Logging<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Log all API interactions:

import logging
from taskflow import Client

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

client = Client(api_key="your_key")

try:
    task = client.tasks.create(title="Deploy feature")
    logger.info(
        "Task created",
        extra={
            "task_id": task.id,
            "title": task.title,
            "status": task.status
        }
    )
except Exception as e:
    logger.error(
        "Task creation failed",
        extra={"error": str(e)},
        exc_info=True
    )

docs.title: Metrics<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
Track key metrics: ✅

  • API request count and latency
  • Error rates by endpoint
  • Rate limit usage
  • Webhook delivery success rate 💡

Example with Prometheus:

from prometheus_client import Counter, Histogram

api_requests = Counter(
    'taskflow_api_requests_total',
    'Total TaskFlow API requests',
    ['method', 'endpoint', 'status']
)

api_latency = Histogram(
    'taskflow_api_request_duration_seconds',
    'TaskFlow API request latency'
)

@api_latency.time()
def create_task(title):
    try:
        task = client.tasks.create(title=title)
        api_requests.labels(
            method='POST',
            endpoint='/tasks',
            status='success'
        ).inc()
        return task
    except Exception as e:
        api_requests.labels(
            method='POST',
            endpoint='/tasks',
            status='error'
        ).inc()
        raise

docs.title: Error Tracking<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
Integrate with error tracking services:

import sentry_sdk
from taskflow import Client

sentry_sdk.init(
    dsn="your_sentry_dsn",
    traces_sample_rate=0.1
)

try:
    task = client.tasks.create(title="Deploy")
except Exception as e:
    sentry_sdk.capture_exception(e)
    raise

docs.title: Connection Pooling<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Reuse HTTP connections:

from taskflow import Client

# Create client once, reuse for all requests
client = Client(
    api_key="your_key",
    pool_connections=10,
    pool_maxsize=20
)

docs.title: Caching<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
Cache frequently accessed data:

from functools import lru_cache
import time

@lru_cache(maxsize=1000)
def get_task_cached(task_id):
    return client.tasks.get(task_id)

# Clear cache periodically
def clear_old_cache():
    get_task_cached.cache_clear()

docs.title: Async Operations<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
Use async I/O for better concurrency:

import asyncio
from taskflow.aio import AsyncClient

async def create_multiple_tasks(titles):
    """Create multiple tasks concurrently."""
    async with AsyncClient(api_key="your_key") as client:
        tasks = await asyncio.gather(*[
            client.tasks.create(title=title)
            for title in titles
        ])
    return tasks

# Create 10 tasks concurrently
titles = [f"Task {i}" for i in range(10)]
tasks = asyncio.run(create_multiple_tasks(titles))

This is significantly faster than sequential requests. ✅

docs.title: Redundancy<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Deploy multiple instances across availability zones:

Load Balancer
    ├── Instance 1 (us-east-1a)
    ├── Instance 2 (us-east-1b)
    └── Instance 3 (us-east-1c)

docs.title: Graceful Degradation<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
Handle API failures gracefully:

def create_task_safe(title):
    """Create task with fallback behavior."""
    try:
        return client.tasks.create(title=title)
    except Exception as e:
        logger.error(f"TaskFlow API failed: {e}")
        # Fallback: Store in local queue for retry
        local_queue.enqueue(title)
        return None

docs.title: Circuit Breaker<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
Implement circuit breaker pattern:

from pybreaker import CircuitBreaker

breaker = CircuitBreaker(
    fail_max=5,
    timeout_duration=60
)

@breaker
def create_task_with_breaker(title):
    return client.tasks.create(title=title)

docs.title: API Key Security<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
• ❌ Never log API keys ✅
  • ❌ Never expose keys in error messages
  • ❌ Never send keys in URLs or query parameters ❗
  • ✅ Rotate keys regularly (every 90 days)
  • ✅ Use separate keys for each environment
  • ✅ Revoke unused keys immediately

docs.title: Network Security<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
• Use TLS 1.2 or higher
  • Implement IP allowlisting for webhooks 💡
  • Use VPC endpoints in AWS for private connectivity
  • Enable webhook signature verification

docs.title: Rate Limit Planning<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
Calculate your rate limit needs:

Tasks per day: 100,000
Tasks per minute: 100,000 / 1,440 = ~69
Peak multiplier: 3x
Peak rate: ~207 requests/minute

Recommended plan: Pro (600 req/min)

docs.title: Database Scaling<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
If storing TaskFlow data locally:

  • Use read replicas for queries
  • Implement caching layer (Redis) 💡
  • Archive old completed tasks

docs.title: Connection Timeouts<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Increase timeout for slow networks:

client = Client(
    api_key="your_key",
    timeout=60  # Increase from default 30s
)

docs.title: Memory Leaks<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
Ensure proper client cleanup:

# Bad: Creates new client on every request
def handle_request():
    client = Client(api_key="key")
    return client.tasks.list()

# Good: Reuse client
client = Client(api_key="key")

def handle_request():
    return client.tasks.list()

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: Authenticate with SpiceFlow using CHOAM-issued credentials. ✅

docs.title: CHOAM API Keys
docs.text: All spice harvesting operations require valid CHOAM (Combine Honnete Ober Advancer Mercantiles) authorization. 🛠️

docs.title: Obtaining Your Key
docs.text:
1. Register with CHOAM headquarters on Kaitain ❗
  2. Submit harvesting license and Great House affiliation
  3. Pay licensing fee (10,000 solaris + Imperial tithe)
  4. Receive key via Guild heighliner 🚨

docs.title: Making Authenticated Requests
docs.text:
from spiceflow import Client

client = Client(
    api_key="sf_choam_your_key",
    planet="arrakis"
)

# All requests authenticated automatically
harvests = client.harvests.list()

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• Never share keys with rival Great Houses 💡
  • Rotate keys after Mentat security audits
  • Store in Ixian no-field encryption 🔍

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Start your first harvest
  • Track sandworms

docs.title: Spice Harvests API
docs.text: The Harvests API allows you to create, monitor, and manage spice harvesting operations across Arrakis. ✅

docs.title: Endpoints
docs.text: Method Endpoint Description POST /v2/harvests GET /v2/harvests List all active harvests GET /v2/harvests/{id} Get specific harvest status PATCH /v2/harvests/{id} DELETE /v2/harvests/{id} Emergency abort (loses equipment!) POST /v2/harvests/{id}/extract

docs.title: The Harvest Object
docs.text:
{
  "id": "harvest_sietchtabr_001",
  "location": {
    "latitude": 22.5,
    "longitude": -45.3,
    "region": "Deep Desert",
    "sietch_proximity_km": 15.2
  },
  "harvester_id": "harvester-7",
  "carryall_id": "carryall-3",
  "status": "active",
  "crew": {
    "size": 20,
    "commander": "Stilgar",
    "fremen_guides": 2,
    "water_reserve_liters": 150
  },
  "spice": {
    "collected_kg": 450.5,
    "estimated_total_kg": 500,
    "purity_grade": "A+",
    "spice_essence_detected": true
  },
  "wormsign": {
    "detected": true,
    "distance_meters": 2500,
    "estimated_size": "large",
    "estimated_age_years": 350,
    "fremen_name": "Old Father"
  },
  "thumpers": {
    "active": 3,
    "pattern": "standard",
    "effectiveness": 0.85
  },
  "started_at": "10191-07-15T06:30:00Z",
  "estimated_completion": "10191-07-15T10:30:00Z",
  "actual_completion": null
}

docs.title: Field Descriptions<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
• id (string) - Unique harvest identifier
  • location (object) - Desert coordinates ❗
  • sietch_proximity_km - Distance to nearest Fremen sietch (important!) 🚨
  • status (enum) - deploying, active, extracting, completed, lost_to_sandworm
  • crew (object) - Crew information ✅
  • spice (object) - Melange collection metrics
  • purity_grade - A+ to F 🔍
  • wormsign (object) - Sandworm threat data 🛠️

docs.title: Deploy a Harvester
docs.text: POST /v2/harvests

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text:
{
  "location": {"latitude": 22.5, "longitude": -45.3},
  "harvester_id": "harvester-7",
  "carryall_id": "carryall-3",
  "crew_size": 20,
  "thumper_pattern": "standard",
  "fremen_guide_requested": true
}

docs.title: Example (Python)<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
harvest = client.harvests.create(
    location={"latitude": 22.5, "longitude": -45.3},
    harvester_id="harvester-7",
    crew_size=20
)

docs.title: Emergency Extraction<sup>          ❗      </sup>
docs.text:
POST /v2/harvests/{harvest_id}/extract

Use when wormsign detected within 500 meters.

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "extraction_status": "carryall_dispatched",
  "eta_seconds": 45,
  "harvester_saved": true
}

docs.title: 409 Conflict - Wormsign Too Close
docs.text:
{
  "error": {
    "code": "wormsign_detected",
    "message": "Cannot deploy: wormsign within safety radius",
    "wormsign": {
      "distance_meters": 350,
      "recommendation": "Wait 2 hours"
    }
  }
}

docs.title: 403 Forbidden - Sacred Ground
docs.text:
{
  "error": {
    "code": "fremen_sacred_site",
    "message": "Location is within Fremen sacred boundaries",
    "sietch": "Sietch Tabr"
  }
}

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Sandworm Tracking
  • Wormsign Webhooks
  • Authentication

docs.title: Sandworm Tracking API
docs.text:
Monitor, track, and predict sandworm (Shai-Hulud) movements across Arrakis. 🚨

  • Status:* ✅ Stable - Trusted by spice harvesters for 80+ years ⏳

docs.title: What are Sandworms?
docs.text: Sandworms (called "Shai-Hulud" or "Old Man of the Desert" by the Fremen) are massive creatures that patrol the deep desert of Arrakis. 🔍 They are attracted to rhythmic vibrations and are highly territorial.

docs.title: Key Facts<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
• Size: 100-400 meters in length ❗
  • Speed: Up to 40 km/h in open sand
  • Lifespan: Unknown, possibly thousands of years
  • Attraction: Rhythmic vibrations, especially thumpers ✅
  • Danger Level: Extreme - can swallow a harvester whole

docs.title: The Sandworm Object
docs.text:
{
  "id": "worm_shai_hulud_42",
  "estimated_length_meters": 350,
  "estimated_age_years": 800,
  "last_sighting": {
    "timestamp": "10191-07-15T08:45:00Z",
    "location": {"latitude": 22.8, "longitude": -45.1},
    "reported_by": "Fremen scout",
    "confidence": "high"
  },
  "movement_pattern": {
    "direction": "northeast",
    "speed_kmh": 35,
    "predicted_path": [...],
    "erratic_behavior": false
  },
  "fremen_designation": "Old Father",
  "threat_level": "extreme",
  "territorial_range_km": 50,
  "last_fed_hours_ago": 12,
  "rings_visible": 23,
  "has_maker_hooks": false
}

docs.title: Field Descriptions<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
• id (string) - Unique worm identifier ❗
  • estimated_length_meters - Length based on ring count
  • estimated_age_years - Age estimate (inexact) 🔍
  • fremen_designation - Name given by Fremen (if known)
  • rings_visible - Body segment rings (age indicator) 🛠️
  • has_maker_hooks - Whether worm has been ridden by Fremen ⏳

docs.title: List Nearby Sandworms
docs.text: GET /v2/sandworms

docs.title: Query Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Description latitude float longitude float Center longitude radius_km float Search radius (default: 50km, max: 500km) min_size integer threat_level string low, medium, high, extreme active_only boolean Only show worms active in last 24 hours fremen_verified boolean

docs.title: Example Request
docs.text:
curl "https://api.spiceflow.arrakis/v2/sandworms?latitude=22.5&longitude=-45.3&radius_km=25" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer sf_choam_your_key"

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "worm_42",
      "estimated_length_meters": 350,
      "distance_from_query_km": 12.5,
      "bearing_degrees": 45,
      "threat_level": "extreme",
      "eta_minutes": 20
    }
  ],
  "warnings": [
    "2 extremely large worms detected within 50km",
    "Coriolis storm may affect worm behavior in next 6 hours"
  ],
  "fremen_advice": "Three worms in formation - very rare. Suggest avoiding area."
}

docs.title: Get Specific Sandworm
docs.text:
GET /v2/sandworms/{worm_id}

Returns detailed information about a specific sandworm, including movement history and predictions. 💡

docs.title: Wormsign Prediction<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
POST /v2/sandworms/predict

Predict sandworm activity for a given location and time window.

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text:
{
  "location": {"latitude": 22.5, "longitude": -45.3},
  "time_window_hours": 4,
  "harvest_planned": true,
  "thumper_pattern": "standard"
}

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "probability_encounter": 0.65,
  "risk_level": "high",
  "predicted_worms": [
    {
      "id": "worm_42",
      "eta_minutes": 45,
      "confidence": 0.8
    }
  ],
  "recommendations": [
    "Deploy extra thumpers 500m north",
    "Keep carryall on standby",
    "Consider Fremen guide for this operation"
  ],
  "fremen_wisdom": "The worms smell water. Your crew leaks."
}
  • Note:* Predictions are probabilistic. Always monitor actively during operations. 🚨

docs.title: Report Wormsign<sup>          ❗      </sup>
docs.text:
POST /v2/sandworms/sightings

Report a sandworm sighting (helps improve tracking for everyone).

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text:
{
  "timestamp": "10191-07-15T09:30:00Z",
  "location": {"latitude": 22.6, "longitude": -45.2},
  "estimated_size": "massive",
  "distance_meters": 800,
  "movement_direction": "northwest",
  "confidence": "high",
  "evidence": {
    "wormsign_observed": true,
    "rhythmic_disturbance": true,
    "sand_displacement": true,
    "thumper_response": "aggressive"
  },
  "reporter_credentials": "harvester_crew_licensed"
}

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "id": "sighting_789",
  "verified": true,
  "worm_id": "worm_42",
  "contribution_points": 10,
  "bounty_earned_solaris": 500
}

CHOAM pays 500 solaris per verified wormsign report! 🛠️

docs.title: Sandworm Behavior Patterns<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
GET /v2/sandworms/{worm_id}/behavior

Analyze historical behavior patterns for a specific sandworm.

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "worm_id": "worm_42",
  "behaviors": {
    "territorial": true,
    "aggressive_rating": 8.5,
    "thumper_sensitivity": "high",
    "typical_patrol_pattern": "circular",
    "hunting_times": ["dawn", "dusk"],
    "avoids_areas": ["rock_outcroppings", "sietch_tabr_vicinity"]
  },
  "rider_history": {
    "has_been_ridden": true,
    "last_ridden": "10188-03-22",
    "fremen_notes": "Stubborn. Requires experienced rider."
  },
  "danger_assessment": "This worm is particularly aggressive toward harvesters. Recommend 1km safety margin."
}

docs.title: Thumper Integration<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
POST /v2/sandworms/thumper-response

Test how a specific sandworm might respond to different thumper patterns.

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text:
{
  "worm_id": "worm_42",
  "thumper_pattern": "aggressive",
  "thumper_count": 3,
  "thumper_spacing_meters": 200
}

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "effectiveness": 0.75,
  "predicted_worm_behavior": "attracted_but_cautious",
  "optimal_harvest_window_minutes": 180,
  "risks": [
    "Worm may investigate thumpers directly",
    "Aggressive pattern may attract additional worms"
  ],
  "fremen_recommendation": "Standard pattern is safer for this worm"
}

docs.title: Maker Hooks<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
GET /v2/sandworms/rideable
  • Fremen-Only Endpoint* - Requires special authorization. 🚨

Returns sandworms suitable for riding (maker hooks).

  • Note:* This endpoint is restricted out of respect for Fremen traditions and for safety reasons. ❗

docs.title: Emergency Alerts<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Subscribe to automatic wormsign alerts via Webhooks:

client.webhooks.create(
    url="https://yourapp.arrakis/wormsign",
    events=["sandworm.detected", "sandworm.approaching"],
    filters={
        "location_radius_km": 10,
        "min_threat_level": "high"
    }
)

docs.title: Historical Data<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
GET /v2/sandworms/history

Access historical sandworm activity data (useful for pattern analysis).

docs.title: Query Parameters
docs.text:
• region - Geographic region
  • start_date / end_date - Date range (Imperial calendar)
  • min_size - Filter by size ✅

docs.title: Safety First
docs.text:
• Never ignore wormsign within 2km 🚨
  • Always have carryall ready for extraction
  • Trust Fremen advice - they know the worms best
  • When in doubt, abort the harvest

docs.title: Respecting Shai-Hulud<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
The Fremen revere sandworms as sacred. When using this API:

  • Don't use disrespectful terminology
  • Honor Fremen knowledge and expertise 💡
  • Report any worm injuries to Fremen authorities
  • Never disturb worms unnecessarily

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Predictions are 70-85% accurate (Fremen intuition is still superior) 🔍
  • Coriolis storms interfere with tracking
  • Some worms avoid detection (stealth worms?) ❗
  • Baby sandworms ("sandtrout") not tracked by this API ✅

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Set up Wormsign Webhooks
  • Learn about Spice Harvests
  • Understand Rate Limiting
  • "Bless the Maker and His water. Bless the coming and going of Him."* - Fremen prayer ⏳

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Install the SpiceFlow SDK for your preferred language. ✅

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher (or equivalent in Guild Standard Time) ❗
  • pip or uv package manager
  • Basic knowledge of spice harvesting operations

docs.title: Install via pip
docs.text: pip install spiceflow-sdk

docs.title: Install via uv<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text: uv pip install spiceflow-sdk

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Node.js 16 or higher 🚨
  • npm, yarn, or pnpm
  • Functioning stillsuit (recommended for desert deployments)

docs.title: Install via npm
docs.text: npm install @spiceflow/sdk

docs.title: Install via yarn
docs.text: yarn add @spiceflow/sdk

docs.title: Fremen Chakobsa<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
For operations in deep desert sietches:

usul install spiceflow --stillsuit-compatible
  • Note*: Requires water reclamation system v2.0 or higher. ⏳

docs.title: Guild Navigator Edition
docs.text:
For Spacing Guild navigators with access to prescient abilities: 💡 

fold-space install spiceflow-navigator-edition

Requires: - Spice gas saturation chamber - Third-stage Guild Navigator certification ❗ - Ability to see all possible futures

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text:
After installation, configure your CHOAM credentials: 🛠️ 

export SPICEFLOW_API_KEY=your_choam_api_key_here
export SPICEFLOW_PLANET=arrakis
export SPICEFLOW_WORMSIGN_ALERTS=true
export FREMEN_RESPECT_LEVEL=high

For Harkonnen operations, use additional environment variables: 🚨 

export ENABLE_BRUTAL_SUPPRESSION=false  # Recommended: false
export RESPECT_FREMEN_WATER_RIGHTS=true  # Required by Imperial decree

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Test your installation: ✅ 

import spiceflow

client = spiceflow.Client()
status = client.ping()

print(status)  # Should print: {"status": "the spice must flow"}

If you see {"status": "sandworm approaching"}, evacuate immediately and check the troubleshooting guide. ✅

docs.title: Stillsuit Compatibility
docs.text:
SpiceFlow SDK is compatible with all standard stillsuits: 🔍

  • Fremen Traditional (99.3% water reclamation)
  • Atreides Military Grade
  • Guild Navigator Environment Suits ❗
  • Harkonnen Standard (lower quality, not recommended)

docs.title: Desert Survival Tips<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
When running SpiceFlow in desert conditions:

  1. Always walk without rhythm to avoid attracting sandworms 💡
  2. Preserve your body's moisture
  3. Respect the Fremen and their ways
  4. Never waste water (including in your code - avoid memory leaks!) ⏳

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text:
• SDK may behave unpredictably during Coriolis storms 🚨
  • Spice gas saturation may affect floating-point calculations 🔍
  • Bene Gesserit monitoring may intercept API calls ❗

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Get your CHOAM API key
  • Track your first spice harvest
  • Learn about sandworm detection

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get your first spice harvester operational in 5 minutes. ⏳

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have:

  • SpiceFlow SDK installed (Installation Guide)
  • A CHOAM-issued API key (Get one here)
  • Basic knowledge of sandworm ecology ❗
  • A stillsuit (strongly recommended)

docs.title: Step 1: Initialize the Client
docs.text:
Create a client instance with your CHOAM credentials: 🛠️ 

from spiceflow import Client

client = Client(
    api_key="sf_choam_1234567890abcdef",
    planet="arrakis",
    wormsign_alerts=True,
    fremen_respect_level="high"
)

docs.title: Step 2: Deploy a Harvester
docs.text:
harvest = client.harvests.create(
    location="22.5°N, 45.3°W",  # Deep desert coordinates
    harvester_id="harvester-7",
    crew_size=20,
    expected_yield="500kg",  # melange
    carryall_id="carryall-3",  # For emergency extraction
    thumper_pattern="standard"  # Keep sandworms at bay
)

print(f"Harvest started: {harvest.id}")
print(f"Estimated completion: {harvest.completion_time}")

The thumper_pattern field accepts: standard, aggressive, stealth, or fremen-style. ✅

docs.title: Step 3: Monitor for Wormsign
docs.text:
Keep checking for approaching sandworms: 🛠️ 

import time

while harvest.status == "active":
    harvest.refresh()

    if harvest.wormsign_detected:
        print(f"WORMSIGN! Distance: {harvest.worm_distance_meters}m")
        print(f"Worm size: {harvest.worm_estimated_size} (approx {harvest.worm_age_years} years old)")

        if harvest.worm_distance_meters < 500:
            # Emergency extraction!
            harvest.emergency_extraction()
            print("Carryall dispatched!")
            break

    time.sleep(10)  # Check every 10 seconds

docs.title: Step 4: Complete the Harvest<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
Once spice collection is complete:

result = harvest.complete()

print(f"Spice collected: {result.spice_yield_kg} kg")
print(f"Purity grade: {result.purity_grade}")  # A+ to F
print(f"Crew status: {result.crew_status}")  # hopefully "alive"
print(f"Equipment damage: {result.damage_report}")

docs.title: Step 5: Report to CHOAM
docs.text:
Submit harvest data to the Combine Honnete Ober Advancer Mercantiles: 🚨 

client.reports.submit_to_choam(
    harvest_id=harvest.id,
    revenue=result.spice_yield_kg * 500000,  # solaris per kg
    imperial_tithe=0.10,  # 10% to Emperor
    guild_payment=0.15  # 15% to Spacing Guild
)

docs.title: Working with Sandworms
docs.text:
Monitor all sandworm activity in your operational area: 🔍 

# Get nearby sandworms
worms = client.sandworms.list(
    location=harvest.location,
    radius_km=50
)

for worm in worms:
    print(f"Worm {worm.id}: {worm.estimated_length_meters}m long")
    print(f"Last seen: {worm.last_sighting}")
    print(f"Fremen name: {worm.fremen_designation}")  # e.g., "Shai-Hulud"

The oldest and largest are called "Shai-Hulud" by the Fremen. ⏳

docs.title: Fremen Relations<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
Manage relationships with local Fremen sietches:

# Record water debt (very important!)
client.fremen.record_water_debt(
    sietch="sietch-tabr",
    debt_liters=50,
    reason="Borrowed water during storm",
    repayment_plan="Next shipment"
)

# Check your standing
standing = client.fremen.get_standing(sietch="sietch-tabr")
print(f"Fremen standing: {standing.reputation}")  # "honored", "tolerated", "marked_for_death"

Never underestimate the importance of water debt. 💡

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Always handle sandworm emergencies gracefully: 🛠️ 

from spiceflow.exceptions import SandwormError, SpiceStormError, FremenHostilityError

try:
    harvest = client.harvests.create(location="25.0°N, 40.0°W")
except SandwormError as e:
    print(f"Wormsign detected before deployment: {e.worm_size}")
    print(f"Recommended action: {e.recommendation}")  # "Abort mission"
except SpiceStormError as e:
    print(f"Coriolis storm incoming: {e.storm_intensity}")
    print(f"Shelter recommended for: {e.duration_hours} hours")
except FremenHostilityError as e:
    print(f"Fremen sietch {e.sietch} has forbidden this location")
    print(f"Reason: {e.reason}")  # Probably sacred ground
    print(f"Alternative locations: {e.alternatives}")

docs.text:

docs.title: Always Respect the Desert<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
• Monitor wormsign constantly
  • Never harvest near Fremen sacred sites 🚨
  • Keep your stillsuit in good repair
  • The spice must flow, but so must you live to harvest another day

docs.title: Crew Safety
docs.text:
# Check crew readiness before deployment
crew = client.crews.get(crew_id="crew-alpha")

if crew.stillsuit_condition < 0.8:
    print("Warning: Stillsuit maintenance needed")

if crew.water_reserve_liters < 5:
    print("Critical: Water reserves too low")

if crew.spice_tolerance < 0.5:
    print("Warning: Crew needs spice acclimatization training")

docs.title: Equipment Maintenance<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
Always check equipment before deployment:

harvester = client.harvesters.inspect(harvester_id="harvester-7")

if harvester.sand_compactor_wear > 0.7:
    harvester.schedule_maintenance()

if harvester.spice_filtration_efficiency < 0.9:
    harvester.replace_filters()

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Ignoring wormsign - The most common cause of harvester loss 🔍
  2. Walking with rhythm - Attracts sandworms unnecessarily 💡
  3. Disrespecting Fremen - Can result in total mission failure (and death)
  4. Insufficient thumpers - Keep at least 3 active per harvest site ✅

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text: Understand TaskFlow API rate limits and how to handle them. ✅

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: TaskFlow implements rate limiting to ensure fair usage and maintain service reliability. ⏳ All API requests count toward your rate limit.

docs.title: Rate Limit Tiers<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Your rate limit depends on your API key type and account plan:

Plan Key Type Requests/Minute Requests/Hour Burst Limit Free Live 60 1,000 Pro Live 600 20,000 1,000 Enterprise Live 6,000 200,000 All Plans Test 100 2,000 All Plans Read-Only 300 10,000 500

docs.title: Burst Limit<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text: The burst limit allows short spikes above your per-minute rate. Once exhausted, requests are limited to your sustained rate.

docs.title: Rate Limit Headers
docs.text:
Every API response includes rate limit information in headers: 💡 

X-RateLimit-Limit: 600
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 543
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1707577200
X-RateLimit-Retry-After: 42

docs.title: Header Descriptions<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
• X-RateLimit-Limit - Total requests allowed per window
  • X-RateLimit-Remaining - Requests remaining in current window ❗
  • X-RateLimit-Reset - Unix timestamp when the limit resets
  • X-RateLimit-Retry-After - Seconds until you can retry (only present when rate limited)

docs.title: 429 Too Many Requests<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
When you exceed your rate limit, the API returns:

HTTP/1.1 429 Too Many Requests
X-RateLimit-Limit: 600
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 0
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1707577200
X-RateLimit-Retry-After: 42
Retry-After: 42
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "error": {
    "code": "rate_limit_exceeded",
    "message": "Rate limit exceeded. Retry after 42 seconds.",
    "retry_after": 42,
    "limit": 600,
    "window": "minute"
  }
}

docs.title: Python Example
docs.text:
import time
from taskflow import Client
from taskflow.exceptions import RateLimitError

client = Client(api_key="your_key")

def create_task_with_retry(title):
    """Create a task with automatic retry on rate limit."""
    max_retries = 3

    for attempt in range(max_retries):
        try:
            return client.tasks.create(title=title)
        except RateLimitError as e:
            if attempt < max_retries - 1:
                wait_time = e.retry_after
                print(f"Rate limited. Waiting {wait_time}s...")
                time.sleep(wait_time)
            else:
                raise

This example shows basic retry logic with exponential backoff. ✅

docs.title: JavaScript Example<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
const taskflow = require('@taskflow/sdk');

async function createTaskWithRetry(title) {
  const maxRetries = 3;

  for (let attempt = 0; attempt < maxRetries; attempt++) {
    try {
      return await taskflow.tasks.create({ title });
    } catch (error) {
      if (error.code === 'rate_limit_exceeded' && attempt < maxRetries - 1) {
        const waitTime = error.retryAfter * 1000;
        console.log(`Rate limited. Waiting ${waitTime}ms...`);
        await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, waitTime));
      } else {
        throw error;
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: 1. Respect the Retry-After Header 🚨
docs.text:
Always wait at least the Retry-After duration before retrying:

if response.status_code == 429:
    retry_after = int(response.headers['Retry-After'])
    time.sleep(retry_after)

docs.title: 2. Implement Exponential Backoff<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
For transient errors, use exponential backoff:

def exponential_backoff(attempt, base=2, max_wait=60):
    """Calculate exponential backoff delay."""
    wait = min(base ** attempt, max_wait)
    return wait

docs.title: 3. Cache Responses<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
Cache API responses that don't change frequently:

import time

cache = {}

def get_task_cached(task_id, ttl=60):
    """Get task with caching."""
    now = time.time()

    if task_id in cache:
        task, timestamp = cache[task_id]
        if now - timestamp < ttl:
            return task

    task = client.tasks.get(task_id)
    cache[task_id] = (task, now)
    return task

docs.title: 4. Use Webhooks Instead of Polling<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
Instead of repeatedly polling for updates, use webhooks to receive real-time notifications:

# ❌ Bad: Polling every second
while True:
    tasks = client.tasks.list(status="updated")
    process_tasks(tasks)
    time.sleep(1)  # Wastes rate limit!

# ✅ Good: Use webhooks
# Register webhook once, receive updates automatically
webhook = client.webhooks.create(
    url="https://yourapp.com/hooks",
    events=["task.updated"]
)

docs.title: 5. Batch Requests<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
When possible, batch multiple operations into single requests:

# ❌ Bad: 100 separate requests
for task_id in task_ids:
    client.tasks.update(task_id, status="completed")

# ✅ Better: Batch update (coming soon)
client.tasks.batch_update(
    task_ids=task_ids,
    updates={"status": "completed"}
)

docs.title: 6. Distribute Requests<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Spread requests evenly throughout your rate limit window:

import time

def rate_limited_loop(items, requests_per_minute=60):
    """Process items within rate limit."""
    delay = 60.0 / requests_per_minute

    for item in items:
        process_item(item)
        time.sleep(delay)

docs.title: Monitoring Rate Limit Usage<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
Check your rate limit status: ❗ 

# Check current rate limit status
response = client._request('GET', '/v2/tasks')
remaining = int(response.headers['X-RateLimit-Remaining'])
limit = int(response.headers['X-RateLimit-Limit'])
usage_percent = (1 - remaining / limit) * 100

print(f"Rate limit usage: {usage_percent:.1f}%")

docs.title: Rate Limit Exemptions<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
Certain endpoints have different limits: 🛠️

  • Health Check (GET /v2/health) - Not rate limited ✅
  • Webhooks (incoming) - 1000 events/minute
  • Bulk Exports - 10 requests/hour (to prevent abuse) 🔍

docs.title: Increasing Your Limit
docs.text:
Need higher rate limits? 🛠️

  • Pro Plan: Upgrade your account
  • Enterprise: Contact sales for custom limits
  • Temporary Increase: Submit a request for event-specific increases ❗

docs.title: "Rate limit exceeded" immediately after reset<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
Your system clock may be out of sync. Sync with NTP:

sudo ntpdate -s time.apple.com

docs.title: Inconsistent rate limit across requests<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
Rate limits are enforced per API key across all requests. If multiple servers use the same key, they share the limit.

  • Solution*: Use separate API keys for different services or implement client-side coordination. ✅

docs.title: Hitting limits with low request volume<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text: Check for: - Polling loops making frequent requests - Webhooks triggering API calls creating feedback loops 🚨 - Multiple instances using the same API key

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Set up Webhooks to reduce polling
  • Explore the Tasks API
  • Learn about authentication

docs.title: Webhooks
docs.text: Receive real-time notifications when events occur in TaskFlow. ✅

docs.title: What are Webhooks?
docs.text: Webhooks allow your application to receive HTTP callbacks when specific events happen, enabling real-time integrations. ⏳

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Sync tasks with external project management tools 💡
  • Send notifications to Slack or Microsoft Teams
  • Update analytics dashboards in real-time 🔍
  • Trigger CI/CD pipelines when deployment tasks complete
  • Log events to external monitoring systems ❗

docs.title: Webhook Events
docs.text:
TaskFlow sends webhooks for these events: 🚨

Event Type Description Payload Includes task.created New task created task.updated Task modified Updated task + changed fields task.deleted Task deleted task.completed Task marked complete Full task object task.assigned Task assigned to user comment.created Comment added Comment + task reference workflow.triggered Workflow executed

docs.title: Create a Webhook Endpoint
docs.text:
Your endpoint must: 🛠️

  • Accept POST requests
  • Respond with 200 OK within 5 seconds ❗
  • Verify the webhook signature (recommended) 🚨

Example endpoint (Python/Flask):

from flask import Flask, request
import hmac
import hashlib

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/webhooks/taskflow', methods=['POST'])
def handle_webhook():
    # Verify signature
    signature = request.headers.get('X-TaskFlow-Signature')
    if not verify_signature(request.data, signature):
        return 'Invalid signature', 401

    # Process webhook
    event = request.json
    event_type = event['type']

    if event_type == 'task.created':
        handle_task_created(event['data'])
    elif event_type == 'task.updated':
        handle_task_updated(event['data'])

    return 'OK', 200

def verify_signature(payload, signature):
    """Verify webhook signature."""
    secret = 'your_webhook_secret'
    expected = hmac.new(
        secret.encode(),
        payload,
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    return hmac.compare_digest(signature, expected)

This example shows basic webhook handling with signature verification. ✅

docs.title: Register Your Webhook
docs.text: POST /v2/webhooks

docs.title: Request Body<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
{
  "url": "https://yourapp.com/webhooks/taskflow",
  "events": ["task.created", "task.updated", "task.completed"],
  "secret": "your_generated_secret_key",
  "enabled": true
}

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "id": "wh_abc123",
  "url": "https://yourapp.com/webhooks/taskflow",
  "events": ["task.created", "task.updated", "task.completed"],
  "enabled": true,
  "created_at": "2024-02-10T15:00:00Z",
  "last_triggered": null,
  "delivery_success_rate": 0.0
}

docs.title: Example (Python SDK)<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
webhook = client.webhooks.create(
    url="https://yourapp.com/webhooks/taskflow",
    events=["task.created", "task.updated"],
    secret="your_secret_key"
)

docs.title: Webhook Payload
docs.text:
All webhook payloads follow this structure: ⏳ 

{
  "id": "evt_xyz789",
  "type": "task.created",
  "timestamp": "2024-02-10T16:45:22Z",
  "data": {
    "id": "task_abc123",
    "title": "Deploy to production",
    "status": "open",
    "priority": "high",
    ...
  },
  "metadata": {
    "account_id": "acc_123",
    "triggered_by": "user_456"
  }
}

docs.title: Headers<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
TaskFlow includes these headers with webhook requests:

Content-Type: application/json
X-TaskFlow-Event: task.created
X-TaskFlow-Signature: sha256=abc123...
X-TaskFlow-Delivery-ID: del_xyz789
  • X-TaskFlow-Event - The event type ❗
  • X-TaskFlow-Signature - HMAC signature for verification
  • X-TaskFlow-Delivery-ID - Unique delivery attempt ID (for deduplication) 💡

docs.title: Signature Verification
docs.text: Always verify webhook signatures to ensure requests are from TaskFlow: 🚨

docs.title: Verification Steps
docs.text:
1. Extract the signature from the X-TaskFlow-Signature header
  2. Compute HMAC-SHA256 of the raw request body using your secret
  3. Compare the computed signature with the received signature 🛠️

docs.title: Example (Python)
docs.text:
import hmac
import hashlib

def verify_webhook(payload, signature, secret):
    """Verify TaskFlow webhook signature."""
    expected_signature = hmac.new(
        secret.encode('utf-8'),
        payload.encode('utf-8'),
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()

    # Prefix with 'sha256='
    expected = f"sha256={expected_signature}"

    # Use constant-time comparison
    return hmac.compare_digest(signature, expected)

docs.title: Example (Node.js)<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
const crypto = require('crypto');

function verifyWebhook(payload, signature, secret) {
  const hmac = crypto.createHmac('sha256', secret);
  hmac.update(payload);
  const expected = `sha256=${hmac.digest('hex')}`;

  return crypto.timingSafeEqual(
    Buffer.from(signature),
    Buffer.from(expected)
  );
}

docs.title: Delivery Guarantees<sup>          🔍      </sup>
docs.text:
• Webhooks are delivered at least once
  • Delivery order is not guaranteed ❗
  • Failed deliveries are retried automatically

docs.title: Retry Policy<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
If your endpoint returns a non-2xx status code or times out:

  1. First retry: after 5 seconds
  2. Second retry: after 30 seconds
  3. Third retry: after 5 minutes
  4. Fourth retry: after 1 hour ⏳
  5. Fifth retry: after 6 hours

After 5 failed attempts, the webhook is marked as failed and deliveries stop. 💡

docs.title: Monitoring Webhooks<sup>          ✅      </sup>
docs.text:
Check webhook delivery status:

GET /v2/webhooks/{webhook_id}/deliveries

Returns recent delivery attempts with status codes and response times.

docs.title: Send Test Event<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Trigger a test webhook delivery:

POST /v2/webhooks/{webhook_id}/test

{
  "event_type": "task.created"
}

Sends a sample webhook to your endpoint for testing. ✅

docs.title: Local Development<sup>          💡      </sup>
docs.text:
For local testing, use a tool like ngrok to expose your local server:

ngrok http 3000

Then register the ngrok URL as your webhook endpoint.

docs.title: Webhook Limits<sup>          🚨      </sup>
docs.text:
• Maximum 10 webhooks per account
  • Maximum 1000 deliveries per webhook per day 🔍
  • Endpoint must respond within 5 seconds
  • Request body size limited to 10MB ❗

docs.title: Handle Duplicate Events<sup>          🛠️      </sup>
docs.text:
Webhooks may be delivered more than once. Use the X-TaskFlow-Delivery-ID header or the event id to deduplicate:

processed_events = set()

def handle_webhook(event):
    event_id = event['id']
    if event_id in processed_events:
        return  # Already processed

    processed_events.add(event_id)
    # Process event...

docs.title: Respond Quickly<sup>          ⏳      </sup>
docs.text:
Process webhooks asynchronously. Respond with 200 OK immediately, then process the event in the background:

@app.route('/webhooks/taskflow', methods=['POST'])
def webhook():
    event = request.json

    # Queue for background processing
    task_queue.enqueue(process_event, event)

    return 'OK', 200

docs.title: Monitor Failures
docs.text: Set up monitoring to alert you when webhook deliveries fail consistently.

docs.title: Use HTTPS
docs.text: Always use HTTPS endpoints for webhooks to protect sensitive data. 🚨

docs.text:
